description: The Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) certification is the gold standard in the IT Security field. Security professionals that have achieved their CISSP designation are regarded as some of the most talented and knowledgeable people in their field. The certification is demonstrates that the holder has been working in IT Security for over five years and has a broad range of knowledge in ten domains related to creating, supporting and maintaining a secure IT infrastructure.
name: Certified Information Systems Security Professional
subtitle: CISSP

episodes.description: Adam and Don introduce the viewers to the CISSP certification. They describe what content is covered by the exam, what prior knowledge you should have, and the requirements to apply for the certification once you pass the exam. They then break down the 10 topic areas that will be covered throughout the show.

of your professional development arc,

440
00:24:18,850 --> 00:24:22,670
you do need to bring CPEs to
the table in order to stay certified.

441
00:24:22,670 --> 00:24:27,640
And the idea here is that as a CISSP,
or even as an SSCP as Don mentioned,

442
00:24:27,640 --> 00:24:31,630
as a starting point, you have to bring a
certain amount of professional development

00:24:31,630 --> 00:24:35,770
to your career arc as you go through and
stay a certified professional.

444
00:24:35,770 --> 00:24:40,680
When you certify as a CISSP, you have
a three year lifecycle on your credential.

445
00:24:40,680 --> 00:24:45,310
And what that means is ultimately,
that every three years you will be

00:24:45,310 --> 00:24:48,960
asked to validate that you have achieved
a certain amount of additional knowledge

447
00:24:48,960 --> 00:24:52,270
through continuing education
in your career field.

448
00:24:52,270 --> 00:24:54,130
And as a result of that, you will then,

449
00:24:54,130 --> 00:24:55,750
I think it's right there,
it's what you're looking for.

450
00:24:55,750 --> 00:24:56,620
>> I know, I can't seem to find it.

451
00:24:56,620 --> 00:24:57,415
>> 120 CPEs, right?

452
00:24:57,415 --> 00:24:57,930
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

453
00:24:57,930 --> 00:25:01,200
So we want, we're gonna have 120 CPEs,
ultimately,

00:25:01,200 --> 00:25:04,460
Continuing Professional Education
credits that are available to you.

455
00:25:04,460 --> 00:25:08,550
Meaning you, as a professional,
have to go out and find opportunities,

456
00:25:08,550 --> 00:25:12,760

engage in projects.

457
00:25:12,760 --> 00:25:15,120
There's a million ways to earn CPEs.

458
00:25:15,120 --> 00:25:18,600

which means 40 a year, and

00:25:18,600 --> 00:25:23,460

or may not be audited by ISC squared.

460
00:25:23,460 --> 00:25:26,080

have to document what you did.

461
00:25:26,080 --> 00:25:29,740

as information security professionals.

462
00:25:29,740 --> 00:25:33,470

accurately and honestly your activities,

463
00:25:33,470 --> 00:25:35,250
and as a result, be able to validate them.

464
00:25:35,250 --> 00:25:38,690
There's a small fee as you can see,
every year, of $85.00 currently.

465
00:25:38,690 --> 00:25:41,600

that's what the AMF is for.

00:25:41,600 --> 00:25:44,420

00:25:44,420 --> 00:25:47,410

00:25:47,410 --> 00:25:48,560

00:25:48,560 --> 00:25:51,560

exam every three years to re-validate

00:25:51,560 --> 00:25:55,200

00:25:55,200 --> 00:25:58,820

00:25:58,820 --> 00:26:01,950

00:26:14,700 --> 00:26:16,600

00:26:59,610 --> 00:27:00,460

00:27:00,460 --> 00:27:03,980

00:14:55,600 --> 00:14:58,300
decide whether you can answer it or not.

373
00:14:58,300 --> 00:15:01,320
Don't spend more than about 30 seconds

374
00:15:01,320 --> 00:15:03,195

>> If you can't come up with it in 30

375
00:15:03,195 --> 00:15:04,230
seconds, you're not

00:15:04,230 --> 00:15:07,095
gonna answer that question no matter how
much time you spend on it right now.

377
00:15:07,095 --> 00:15:09,055
>> Right.
>> So as a result, mark it and move on.

378
00:15:09,055 --> 00:15:13,690
This is gonna optimize you to focus on
the ones you can knock-off right away.

379
00:15:13,690 --> 00:15:16,480
Get through all of those,
which is the bulk of the exam.

380
00:15:16,480 --> 00:15:18,300
Right?
Then you're gonna come back and

381
00:15:18,300 --> 00:15:21,970
have somewhere between a half to
maybe a quarter of your time left,

382
00:15:21,970 --> 00:15:23,310
if you do it the right way.

383
00:15:23,310 --> 00:15:27,610
And as a result of that, you're now gonna
go back and be able to spend a minute or

384
00:15:27,610 --> 00:15:28,930
two on these questions.

385
00:15:28,930 --> 00:15:30,030
You've already read once.

386
00:15:30,030 --> 00:15:31,580
>> Right.
>> You got to read them again,

387
00:15:31,580 --> 00:15:34,330
now you're going to take your time and
try to figure out which ones

00:15:34,330 --> 00:15:37,370

the ones you can ignore in the sense of

00:15:37,370 --> 00:15:40,530

390
00:15:40,530 --> 00:15:42,115
Now again, time management.

00:15:42,115 --> 00:15:44,865
Don't spend more than a minute on
these questions at this point.

00:15:44,865 --> 00:15:49,004

00:15:49,004 --> 00:15:51,748

00:15:51,748 --> 00:15:53,601

00:15:53,601 --> 00:15:54,577

Second pass through the exam.

00:15:56,086 --> 00:15:58,635
You're gonna hopefully eliminate
three quarters of the ones that were

00:15:58,635 --> 00:15:59,150

00:16:05,510 --> 00:16:06,790

00:16:10,789 --> 00:16:14,090

00:16:14,090 --> 00:16:16,050
So I'm not suggesting you guess.

00:16:16,050 --> 00:16:19,730

00:16:19,730 --> 00:16:21,860

00:16:21,860 --> 00:16:25,850

00:16:34,085 --> 00:16:34,860

The worse that will happen

You don't know how many there are?

So you have to answer them all, but

70% overall to pass the exam.

00:19:35,070 --> 00:19:37,130

you have to make the critical information

Scenario typically, is available to

Sometimes you get these really

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don discuss physical and logical access controls and how they can be implemented in a corporate environment. They also take a deeper look into authentication and the assorted components that can be used to build an authentication scheme.
episodes.title: Access Controls

1

in general those kind of things.

00:02:54,760 --> 00:03:00,570

those kind of shows and

Sesame Street, another one I guess,

48
00:03:04,210 --> 00:03:08,165
We saw one of the episodes where one of

00:03:08,165 --> 00:03:11,255
Elmo that might have come out and done it,

00:03:11,255 --> 00:03:13,365

51
00:03:13,365 --> 00:03:15,515
Which one of these things does not belong?

52

And so it was a lot more effective when

53
00:03:19,435 --> 00:03:22,205
the point is when we think about

54
00:03:22,205 --> 00:03:25,875

55

Which one of these things

56

Because that's really haw we start

58

59
00:03:37,420 --> 00:03:41,100

60

61
00:03:43,460 --> 00:03:46,940
So wanna have that kind of in our minds,

62

We also want to be thinking about

63
00:03:50,190 --> 00:03:55,080

00:03:55,080 --> 00:03:58,020

65
00:03:58,020 --> 00:04:01,790
No discussion would be complete

66

67

68

Making sure the data is

But during the times and under the ways or

00:04:32,560 --> 00:04:37,150

76
00:04:37,150 --> 00:04:42,020

77
00:04:42,020 --> 00:04:44,300
So we always want to be
focused on thinking about and

78
00:04:44,300 --> 00:04:49,720
understanding confidentiality, integrity,

79
00:04:49,720 --> 00:04:54,360
with that integricity or something.

80
00:04:54,360 --> 00:04:58,818
>> You could argue that maybe I don't

81
00:04:58,818 --> 00:05:00,105
[LAUGH]
>> Maybe you don't.

00:05:00,105 --> 00:05:01,820
Could be a problem, right?

00:05:01,820 --> 00:05:06,630
Alright, so keep an eye on
the vocabulary list as we go.

84
00:05:06,630 --> 00:05:09,390
Make sure Don is a good actor.

85
00:05:09,390 --> 00:05:12,172
Right, in the sense that he's
spelling things correctly.

86
00:05:12,172 --> 00:05:16,230
All right, so we are talking about subject
and object when we talk about data and

87
00:05:16,230 --> 00:05:17,400
access control.

88
00:05:17,400 --> 00:05:20,480
Some other key terms that we want
to make sure we're familiar with,

89
00:05:20,480 --> 00:05:23,200
very important kind of begins
our discussion around data.

90
00:05:23,200 --> 00:05:27,940
The idea of the subject,
the subject is going to be the user.

91
00:05:27,940 --> 00:05:32,450
So when we think of the subject, we are
thinking about effectively an end user or

92
00:05:32,450 --> 00:05:34,590
anybody who wants to access the data.

93
00:05:34,590 --> 00:05:36,200
And when we think about the object,

94
00:05:36,200 --> 00:05:40,720
we are thinking about the data typically
that the subject would like to see.

95
00:05:40,720 --> 00:05:45,030
And so we often talk about access
control in terms of subjects and objects

96
00:05:45,030 --> 00:05:49,280
interacting with one another, and what
level of access we are granting, right?

97
00:05:49,280 --> 00:05:52,610
So, we wanna make sure we understand
the vocabulary, the terminology,

98
00:05:52,610 --> 00:05:54,950
because it is very important to us.

99
00:05:54,950 --> 00:05:59,790
And a lot of these conversations will take
place in relation to subject and object.

100
00:05:59,790 --> 00:06:02,310
We'll be talking about that,
so just be aware of that.

101
00:06:02,310 --> 00:06:05,690
We have different degrees of,
obviously, access controllers.

102
00:06:05,690 --> 00:06:09,690
As we think about confidentiality,
integrity, availability,

103
00:06:09,690 --> 00:06:14,230
we think about the fact that we can give,
or perhaps through shades of gray,

104
00:06:14,230 --> 00:06:17,980
give access control to different groups or
different subjects

105
00:06:17,980 --> 00:06:21,400
based on the objects they want to
interact with in different ways.

106
00:06:21,400 --> 00:06:25,998
And so for an example, somebody who is
gonna be given a read-only access to data,

107
00:06:25,998 --> 00:06:30,130
will be able to see data, but
is not gonna be able to edit the data.

108
00:06:30,130 --> 00:06:34,135
And so while they can see it, they won't
really be able to interact with it fully.

109
00:06:34,135 --> 00:06:39,660
Whereas somebody who is going to be given
the rights to maybe be a contributor for,

110
00:06:39,660 --> 00:06:42,290
think about maybe a webpage or
something like that.

111
00:06:42,290 --> 00:06:45,150
A contributor will have rights to read, so

112
00:06:45,150 --> 00:06:49,180
they have read only, but they have
more than what read only would grant.

113
00:06:49,180 --> 00:06:53,190
And as a result, they can not just
read but they also can modify and

114
00:06:53,190 --> 00:06:57,395
they can add data as well
as probably place data,

115
00:06:57,395 --> 00:07:01,215
whatever we may call that particular
controller, that particular permission.

116
00:07:01,215 --> 00:07:04,615
So, as a result, they will roll
up permissions up underneath

117
00:07:04,615 --> 00:07:08,515
that particular association, being a
member of the contributor group or having

118
00:07:08,515 --> 00:07:13,630
the contributor right, and they will have
a larger or higher level permission.

119
00:07:13,630 --> 00:07:16,120
So we're talking about
different graded levels or

120
00:07:16,120 --> 00:07:20,270
different gradations of access and this is
something that's a theme that often comes

121
00:07:20,270 --> 00:07:23,280
up as we start to talk about
access control as well.

122
00:07:23,280 --> 00:07:26,730
So let's identify some thought
processes and terminology here.

123
00:07:26,730 --> 00:07:30,010
We've already started to do that,
but specifically four key things.

124
00:07:30,010 --> 00:07:33,250
Our focus on rather, I should say.

125
00:07:33,250 --> 00:07:37,950
We want to identify, no pun intended here,
the words identification as a process.

126
00:07:37,950 --> 00:07:39,620
So what is identification?

127
00:07:39,620 --> 00:07:42,243
Right, what is authentication?

128
00:07:42,243 --> 00:07:46,364
[COUGH] What is authorization?

129
00:07:46,364 --> 00:07:48,448
I have a lot of T-I-O-N going on, and

00:07:48,448 --> 00:07:52,746
then accountability because these are the
four operational terms that we use and

131
00:07:52,746 --> 00:07:56,050

talking about access control.

132
00:07:56,050 --> 00:08:00,949
And so identification, operational terms
are just terms that we just want to make

133
00:08:00,949 --> 00:08:03,370
sure we have a kind of a background with.

134
00:08:03,370 --> 00:08:05,800
So we'll just pretty all that up there for

135
00:08:08,000 --> 00:08:11,239
So, identification is gonna be this idea,
or

136
00:08:11,239 --> 00:08:17,380
this process of being able to see who
somebody is when we think about a subject.

137
00:08:17,380 --> 00:08:18,560
So, we think about a user.

138
00:08:18,560 --> 00:08:22,980
So, this describes the ability for
a user to be able to

139
00:08:22,980 --> 00:08:28,110
claim that they are somebody and validate
who they are through another process.

140
00:08:28,110 --> 00:08:31,955
When I pull out my license and
show somebody my license,

141
00:08:31,955 --> 00:08:35,705
I'm identifying myself as Adam Gordon,
for instance.

142
00:08:35,705 --> 00:08:40,075
So, identification is helping us to
determining the identity, not of a user,

143
00:08:40,075 --> 00:08:41,255
let's use the word subject.

144
00:08:41,255 --> 00:08:46,295
Let's get people that are playing along
with us here and listening, let's get

00:08:46,295 --> 00:08:49,015
them used to the language because
the language is gonna be very important.

146
00:08:49,015 --> 00:08:53,995
So, determining the identity of a subject
is what identification can help us to do.

147
00:08:53,995 --> 00:08:59,020
And what we should do is probably,
let's think

148
00:08:59,020 --> 00:09:03,440
of identification as
the first step in a process.

149
00:09:03,440 --> 00:09:08,610
Because typically we ask you to identify
before we ask you to then authenticate and

150
00:09:08,610 --> 00:09:09,470
then to authorize.

151
00:09:09,470 --> 00:09:11,970
So we kind of say, who are you?

152
00:09:11,970 --> 00:09:13,336
We challenge you in some way.

153
00:09:13,336 --> 00:09:17,430
You have to then provide some sort
of credential that will allow us to

154
00:09:17,430 --> 00:09:19,270
engage in authentication.

155
00:09:19,270 --> 00:09:22,210
Which, if it's done successfully,
will then let you authorize.

156
00:09:22,210 --> 00:09:23,810
And then if that is successful,

157
00:09:23,810 --> 00:09:28,660
we then are gonna access the data in
whatever form we are given permission to.

158
00:09:28,660 --> 00:09:31,220
And then accountability is brought in,
because then we can track what you're

159
00:09:31,220 --> 00:09:33,930
doing, and obviously understand
what's happening there.

160
00:09:33,930 --> 00:09:36,020
So, when we talk about authentication,

161
00:09:36,020 --> 00:09:42,370
we are talking about this idea of being
able to validate a user's identity.

162
00:09:42,370 --> 00:09:47,000
So when they provide identification, we
have to validate the subject's identity.

163
00:09:47,000 --> 00:09:50,368
And so this is important because
authentication can take several forms.

164
00:09:50,368 --> 00:09:52,880
It could be a challenge
response of some kind.

165
00:09:52,880 --> 00:09:58,270
It could be a biometric authentication,
where we provide some sort of either

166
00:09:58,270 --> 00:10:03,610
unique identifier or some sort of
combination of factors, have no r.

167
00:10:03,610 --> 00:10:05,515
We'll talk more about these in a while,
but

168
00:10:05,515 --> 00:10:08,650
we'll combine factors of
identification together

169
00:10:08,650 --> 00:10:12,680
in order to create a secure environment or
a more secure environment as we scale up.

170
00:10:12,680 --> 00:10:15,720
Authorization takes place where we take

171
00:10:15,720 --> 00:10:20,210
the authentication information that
has been provided by the subject and

172
00:10:20,210 --> 00:10:26,060
we validate that against a directory of
some kind, an LDAP directory, most likely.

173
00:10:26,060 --> 00:10:27,530
LDAP standard is x.500, so

174
00:10:27,530 --> 00:10:31,000
we probably just wanna throw
that out there really quickly.

175
00:10:31,000 --> 00:10:32,920
That will validate the access

176
00:10:34,760 --> 00:10:39,660
that the subject is requesting against
a directory, an LDAP directory.

177
00:10:39,660 --> 00:10:43,480
And LDAP is important as a reference
because it is a protocol

178
00:10:43,480 --> 00:10:46,550
that is the standard for
directory services today.

179
00:10:46,550 --> 00:10:50,870
So, lightweight directory access
protocol is what LDAP will stand for.

180
00:10:52,870 --> 00:10:58,640
And it will be the [LAUGH]
>> It's early in the morning.

181
00:10:58,640 --> 00:10:59,620
>> It is, I know it is.

182
00:10:59,620 --> 00:11:03,230
And it is x.500 is the standard for
directory for

183
00:11:03,230 --> 00:11:06,240
LDAP directory services, x.500.

184
00:11:06,240 --> 00:11:08,990
So, that is the LDAP standard.

185
00:11:08,990 --> 00:11:13,290
When we say LDAP, we are not talking
necessarily about Microsoft's LDAP,

186
00:11:13,290 --> 00:11:16,700
we're talking generically
just about an LDAP solution.

187
00:11:16,700 --> 00:11:21,095
Microsoft implements LDAP as many,
many other vendors do today.

188
00:11:21,095 --> 00:11:25,240
But they all use the x.500 standard for
LDAP, just so you're clear.

189
00:11:25,240 --> 00:11:26,740
And then we have accountability.

190
00:11:26,740 --> 00:11:30,440
And accountability is about making
sure the access controls are applied

191
00:11:30,440 --> 00:11:31,240
to the subjects and

192
00:11:31,240 --> 00:11:35,670
the objects appropriately as well
as tracking what is going on there.

193
00:11:35,670 --> 00:11:39,930
So we will keep an eye on subjects
coming in to access objects.

194
00:11:39,930 --> 00:11:42,252
We will probably do some auditing.

195
00:11:42,252 --> 00:11:45,480
We will probably have some sort of
mechanism to ensure that they are not

196
00:11:45,480 --> 00:11:49,140
getting into data that they don't
belong seeing, things of that nature.

197
00:11:49,140 --> 00:11:52,552
So, accountability is all about making
sure that the system is working the way

198

1801
01:27:20,840 --> 01:27:23,320
Now what we also want to
understand about Kerberos is,

1802
01:27:23,320 --> 01:27:26,760
this is a time-based

1803
01:27:26,760 --> 01:27:29,790
So much like when you go to a parking

1804
01:27:29,790 --> 01:27:33,320

and then hours later you come back,

1805
01:27:33,320 --> 01:27:36,490
you pay based on the prorated amount
of time you've been in the garage.

1806
01:27:36,490 --> 01:27:38,940
Same concept,
except we're not parking cars.

1807
01:27:38,940 --> 01:27:40,410
We're requesting services.

1808
01:27:40,410 --> 01:27:42,750
So when we get those tickets,
they are timed stamped.

1809
01:27:42,750 --> 01:27:43,410
Which means that,

1810
01:27:43,410 --> 01:27:46,870
if we are not doing time synchronization,
we are going to have a problem.

01:27:46,870 --> 01:27:48,540
So I'll remind you.

But we talk about protocols,

01:28:09,210 --> 01:28:13,030
Network Time Protocol, that is used

01:28:13,030 --> 01:28:15,060

01:28:15,060 --> 01:28:18,057
And this is going to allow

01:28:18,057 --> 01:28:21,535

1822
01:28:21,535 --> 01:28:25,300
Now the key with Kerberos is that you
must keep the domain controllers,

1823
01:28:25,300 --> 01:28:27,430
the KDCs, time synchronized.

1824
01:28:27,430 --> 01:28:31,100
They must be within a five minute
window of synchronization by default.

1825
01:28:31,100 --> 01:28:33,970
Again, this is a variable solution,
could be modified.

1826
01:28:33,970 --> 01:28:37,230
We can use tools like Kerbtray,
which is a management tool for

1827
01:28:37,230 --> 01:28:40,870
Kerberos to look at the tools, or
the tickets rather, that are granted.

1828
01:28:40,870 --> 01:28:43,840
We also could modify this as group policy.

1829
01:28:43,840 --> 01:28:47,330
But we have a five minute time drift
variable here that we can allow for.

1830
01:28:48,750 --> 01:28:52,020
If we get outside the five minute window,
we actually see what is known as a denial

1831
01:28:52,020 --> 01:28:54,820
of service attack being carried
out because we can decouple,

1832
01:28:54,820 --> 01:28:56,600
desynchronize these domain controllers.

1833
01:28:56,600 --> 01:28:59,040
Now it's very easy to fix this problem.

1834
01:28:59,040 --> 01:29:01,310
Just simply resynchronize all
the domain controllers and

1835
01:29:01,310 --> 01:29:02,760
everything starts working again.

1836
01:29:02,760 --> 01:29:04,130
But if you desynchronize,

1837
01:29:04,130 --> 01:29:08,180
if you get outside that five minute
window, literally everything you do stops.

1838
01:29:08,180 --> 01:29:11,680

1839
01:29:11,680 --> 01:29:13,410

1840
01:29:13,410 --> 01:29:17,248
Nobody can access resources, because no
way to authenticate that origination point

01:29:17,248 --> 01:29:19,500
for the ticket based on the time.

01:29:19,500 --> 01:29:23,060

01:29:23,060 --> 01:29:26,130

01:29:26,130 --> 01:29:29,330

the time solution,

01:29:29,330 --> 01:29:34,510

01:29:34,510 --> 01:29:38,150

01:29:38,150 --> 01:29:41,990

01:29:53,140 --> 01:29:54,775

01:29:54,775 --> 01:29:58,465

01:29:58,465 --> 01:29:59,665
But if I log out,

01:30:02,865 --> 01:30:04,055

01:30:04,055 --> 01:30:08,302

1858
01:30:13,012 --> 01:30:17,538

log on, your user information, your sum

1859
01:30:17,538 --> 01:30:21,646

01:30:21,646 --> 01:30:25,073

is generated for you in a token,

Universally Unique ID within the forest,

1862
01:30:30,075 --> 01:30:34,238

logically as you log in.

01:30:34,238 --> 01:30:38,378
That's why SSO works, single sign-on,

01:30:38,378 --> 01:30:42,448

01:30:49,868 --> 01:30:51,808
The reason is the token is static.

01:30:51,808 --> 01:30:52,598

01:30:56,590 --> 01:30:58,640

they may or

01:30:58,640 --> 01:31:01,460

01:31:01,460 --> 01:31:04,340
But because they have that prior
permission associated with

1874
01:31:04,340 --> 01:31:07,020

>> Where you're going to do the overlay

management of that, operating system
patching, and all of that stuff.

00:05:30,890 --> 00:05:33,370
You really only as the end user,
have to focus on or

00:05:33,370 --> 00:05:37,910

111
00:05:37,910 --> 00:05:41,030
That's really the only piece you have

112
00:05:41,030 --> 00:05:42,800
And then infrastructure is a service.

113
00:05:44,200 --> 00:05:46,360
The vendor,
whoever the vendor is gonna to be,

is going to give you that traditional

00:05:50,670 --> 00:05:54,310
Turn key kind of environment where

00:06:13,665 --> 00:06:19,140
will go in and be placed thereby

The goal here would be to really just
understand that whatever we choose to

132
00:06:50,370 --> 00:06:54,418
Which means effectively, you're renting,
you're paying somebody for

134

And, as a result,

00:06:58,600 --> 00:06:59,539

137
00:07:03,430 --> 00:07:07,210

00:07:07,210 --> 00:07:07,750
push one or

more of these layers out to a provider,

In a multi-tenant model.

00:07:13,930 --> 00:07:18,570
A model where we have multiple customers

00:07:18,570 --> 00:07:21,660
And we sit in these little boxes,

00:07:21,660 --> 00:07:24,320

Often the one that is undersold and

You tend to get that kind of

00:08:36,540 --> 00:08:38,510

00:08:45,660 --> 00:08:48,330
What kind of security
parameters are put in place

00:08:48,330 --> 00:08:50,220

00:08:50,220 --> 00:08:51,885

[COUGH] When you go, and

00:08:56,850 --> 00:08:59,640

30 bucks a month per user, or

00:08:59,640 --> 00:09:04,100

you don't have the ability to see that.

00:09:04,100 --> 00:09:05,810
We're not gonna tell you that.

00:09:05,810 --> 00:09:09,160
And we're not going to expose

00:09:19,350 --> 00:09:22,000
Because A, we're too busy,

00:09:26,360 --> 00:09:30,140
And B, you're more secure, in effect,

00:09:33,220 --> 00:09:36,400

00:09:36,400 --> 00:09:40,350
But we're good enough, we're big enough,

00:09:40,350 --> 00:09:44,310

00:09:44,310 --> 00:09:46,630
But as a result you don't
have visibility into that.

So just be aware of that.

00:10:00,770 --> 00:10:05,450
technology and recommend architectures and

00:10:05,450 --> 00:10:09,500
the company down one road versus
another in order to create value.

00:10:09,500 --> 00:10:13,455
And recognize ultimately, at the end
of the day, how you can safely and

00:10:13,455 --> 00:10:17,265
surely provide services, but
do so in an ethical, and

00:10:17,265 --> 00:10:21,655
obviously a focused way that leads
to security if at all possible.

00:10:21,655 --> 00:10:24,045
And so
this is a challenge in today's world.

00:10:24,045 --> 00:10:26,960
We see the same challenge coming out and

00:10:26,960 --> 00:10:31,140

big data moving into the cloud and

what is that gonna look like.

01:48:36,160 --> 01:48:39,940
But the reality is you may go back out to
the real world after you become a CISSP.

2223
01:48:39,940 --> 01:48:42,230
And not too much with
cryptography after that.

2224
01:48:42,230 --> 01:48:45,375
You may implement cryptography here and
there every so often.

2225
01:48:45,375 --> 01:48:47,890
[LAUGH] But
you may not do much with it after that.

2226
01:48:47,890 --> 01:48:50,910
So as a result it may not be your thing,
and I get that.

2227
01:48:50,910 --> 01:48:54,000
Software development and
system development lifecycles may not be

2228
01:48:54,000 --> 01:48:56,870
the purview of most security
professionals today.

2229
01:48:56,870 --> 01:48:58,720
So, you have to understand
what you're good at,

2230
01:48:58,720 --> 01:49:01,780
but also understand where you
have some weaknesses, right?

2231
01:49:01,780 --> 01:49:03,040
Some vulnerabilities, some threats,

2232
01:49:03,040 --> 01:49:06,700
some risks that you wanna help
offset by bringing in experts.

2233
01:49:06,700 --> 01:49:10,170
Talk to your peers,
talk to your colleagues.

2234
01:49:10,170 --> 01:49:14,390
We sit up here we have banter, Don and I,
or Mike and I as we host and we talk about

2235
01:49:14,390 --> 01:49:18,210
things we are comfortable with some things
perhaps not as comfortable with others.

2236
01:49:18,210 --> 01:49:21,250
Some of us you know specialize
in certain areas some of us do

2237
01:49:21,250 --> 01:49:23,190
things on a regular basis others don't and

2238
01:49:23,190 --> 01:49:27,910
so one of us may go deeper on a topic then
another and offer commentary on a topic

2239
01:49:27,910 --> 01:49:30,440
because we have something to share
because it's valuable there.

2240
01:49:30,440 --> 01:49:33,100
So, we kind of have that
tacit working knowledge and

2241
01:49:33,100 --> 01:49:36,890
understanding of the fact that we're both
gonna jump in and talk about things,

2242
01:49:36,890 --> 01:49:40,370
cuz we bring that expertise to
the table to support each other.

2243
01:49:40,370 --> 01:49:41,770
It's a really critical though process,

2244
01:49:41,770 --> 01:49:45,960
you see it at play in every one of the
episodes of IT TV that you work through,

2245
01:49:45,960 --> 01:49:48,440
not just in this topical area but
for any of our programs.

2246
01:49:48,440 --> 01:49:50,280
Or any of our shows, for anything, and

2247
01:49:50,280 --> 01:49:54,220
it's a very very effective way to
understand how to consume information

2248
01:49:54,220 --> 01:49:57,200
because no matter what the focus is,
you're hearing

2249
01:49:57,200 --> 01:50:01,120
the best information from that person
that's most qualified to give it to you.

2250
01:50:01,120 --> 01:50:04,640
And that's really what you have to think
about when you think about being a CISSP

2251
01:50:04,640 --> 01:50:05,490
is, what am I good at?

2252
01:50:05,490 --> 01:50:06,700
What do I know?

2253
01:50:06,700 --> 01:50:10,190
And then where do I have some weaknesses
and where do I need to ask for help?

2254
01:50:10,190 --> 01:50:13,140
And if you can figure that out,
that's probably the single

2255
01:50:13,140 --> 01:50:16,880
most important thing I can teach you or
jointly we can make you aware of.

2256
01:50:16,880 --> 01:50:19,840
If you are humble enough to be
able to understand that and

2257
01:50:19,840 --> 01:50:23,510
do that on a regular basis,
just imagine how incredible

2258
01:50:23,510 --> 01:50:26,590
the networks you going to build and
how secure they're going to be over time.

2259
01:50:26,590 --> 01:50:29,770
So, probably a great way to
leave us with a parting thought.

2260
01:50:29,770 --> 01:50:31,610
>> Yeah, now I feel like we're in church.

2261
01:50:31,610 --> 01:50:33,980
You leave them with a parting thought.

2262
01:50:33,980 --> 01:50:34,810
Honest.

2263
01:50:34,810 --> 01:50:37,036
So the moral of the story is.

2264
01:50:37,036 --> 01:50:38,432
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right,

2265
01:50:38,432 --> 01:50:41,070
I think we wrapped up
networking at this point.

2266
01:50:41,070 --> 01:50:43,660
I obviously a wealth information,
as you know,

2267
01:50:43,660 --> 01:50:45,490
just by the fact we had
you go into part 3.

2268
01:50:45,490 --> 01:50:50,700
So, I do want to remind you guys, if you
have questions on any of this, if you

2269
01:50:50,700 --> 01:50:53,800
want a deeper explanation, keep in mind
that with a lot of this networking stuff,

2270
01:50:53,800 --> 01:50:57,450
you can jump over to The Network Plus show
and we go in depth on a lot of it there.

2271
01:50:57,450 --> 01:51:00,940
But even if you are in a hurry and

2272
01:51:00,940 --> 01:51:03,460
take advantage of the various
ways you can ask us questions.

2273
01:51:03,460 --> 01:51:06,290
Live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live.

2274
01:51:06,290 --> 01:51:10,320
You can post your questions right in

2275
01:51:10,320 --> 01:51:13,900
We see it monitored during the show,

2276
01:51:13,900 --> 01:51:18,480
If you're watching this recorded, after
hours, middle of the night, whatever, use

2277
01:51:18,480 --> 01:51:23,850
the Q&A link at the top of every itpro.tv
web page, head in there, that takes

2278
01:51:23,850 --> 01:51:27,060
you tot he Q&A forms, you can post your

2279
01:51:27,060 --> 01:51:29,770
We want to make sure you guys get

01:51:29,770 --> 01:51:32,900
that your going in to that exam with

2281

That's gonna be one of the keys

>> Lot's of questions on the page.

2283

So you don't want to

2284

They give you enough there, so
make sure you leave them out and

2285
01:51:40,790 --> 01:51:41,970
just take the answers in with you.

2286
01:51:41,970 --> 01:51:43,370
Great advice absolutely.

2287
01:51:43,370 --> 01:51:44,149
>> Absolutely.

2288
01:51:44,149 --> 01:51:48,085
All right well, signing off for

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike discuss some of the fundamentals of security. They cover several different control types as well as take a thorough examine of the risk analysis and management approaches.
episodes.title: Risk and Governance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,878 --> 00:00:37,087
Welcome everybody to another
episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:37,087 --> 00:00:41,420
My name is Mike Rodrick and I'm here today
with very special guest, Mr. Adam Gordon.

4
00:00:41,420 --> 00:00:42,370
How are you doing today, Adam?

5
00:00:42,370 --> 00:00:43,520
I'm good, how about you?

6
00:00:43,520 --> 00:00:44,240
Oh fantastic.

7
00:00:44,240 --> 00:00:44,890
Good. Fantastic. Good.

8
00:00:44,890 --> 00:00:45,550
Couldn't be better.

9
00:00:45,550 --> 00:00:48,840
We're getting ready to dive
into our next episode of CISSP.

10
00:00:48,840 --> 00:00:49,470
We are.

11
00:00:49,470 --> 00:00:53,000
We're going to hit some risk and
governance today, I guess.

12
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:53,780
Yeah, absolutely.

13
00:00:53,780 --> 00:00:57,670
So we're going to talk little bit
about the ideas behind risk and

14
00:00:57,670 --> 00:01:00,800
information security management
from a risk awareness perspective.

15
00:01:00,800 --> 00:01:03,910
Also governance, what is the role
of governance in an organization?

16
00:01:03,910 --> 00:01:04,980
Why is it important?

17
00:01:04,980 --> 00:01:06,500
What are the things we use and

18
00:01:06,500 --> 00:01:10,860
think about in order to be able to drive
governance home with our user community?

19
00:01:10,860 --> 00:01:14,700
When we start talking about information
security in any of the areas, any of

20
00:01:14,700 --> 00:01:18,500
the ten bodies of knowledge that we speak
about within the CISSP, we've gotta start

21
00:01:18,500 --> 00:01:23,470
that conversation, frame that conversation
out by really thinking about three things.

22
00:01:23,470 --> 00:01:26,050
We talk about these as the pillars,
the underlying structures or

23
00:01:26,050 --> 00:01:28,110
pillars of information security.

24
00:01:28,110 --> 00:01:32,540
So we think of them as being
confidentiality, as integrity, and

25
00:01:32,540 --> 00:01:33,260
availability.

26
00:01:33,260 --> 00:01:36,341
I know we've put together, I should say
you, I don't wanna take any credit for it.

27
00:01:36,341 --> 00:01:38,060
[LAUGH] Because you did all the hard work.

28
00:01:38,060 --> 00:01:41,610
All I did was tell you let's look in this
area and let's talk about these things,

29
00:01:41,610 --> 00:01:45,430
but we put together some notes and
some vocabulary we want to share with

30
00:01:45,430 --> 00:01:47,400
everybody, so
if we could put those up on the screen.

31
00:01:47,400 --> 00:01:49,330
Wanna put those up there for us, Jason?

32
00:01:49,330 --> 00:01:52,600
There we go, so we've got the three
items listed there, availability,

33
00:01:52,600 --> 00:01:56,470
integrity, confidentiality These are gonna
be recurring themes for us as we talk

34
00:01:56,470 --> 00:02:01,000
through this material throughout
the entire life cycle of this CISSP.

35
00:02:01,000 --> 00:02:04,480
Confidentiality is gonna be
this idea at the bottom there

36
00:02:04,480 --> 00:02:09,360
of this level of secrecy and
this idea of keeping information secure.

37
00:02:09,360 --> 00:02:11,430
Safeguarding information,

38
00:02:11,430 --> 00:02:14,400
keeping it out of the hands of
people that don't belongs to.

39
00:02:14,400 --> 00:02:15,870
Right.

40
00:02:15,870 --> 00:02:18,920
We had a document perhaps,
maybe we we're a manager,

41
00:02:18,920 --> 00:02:23,090
had a team of people that we work with and
that are underneath us, and

42
00:02:23,090 --> 00:02:27,465
we're doing reviews,
maybe annual reviews or quarterly reviews.

43
00:02:27,465 --> 00:02:28,190
Mm-hm.

44
00:02:28,190 --> 00:02:31,820
We don't want any body else on
the team to see anyone else's reviews.

45
00:02:31,820 --> 00:02:35,190
We don't want other managers to be
able to see other employees, or

46
00:02:35,190 --> 00:02:36,688
other team members of ours' reviews.

47
00:02:36,688 --> 00:02:38,530
Mm-hm.
Nor do we wanna see theirs.

48
00:02:38,530 --> 00:02:41,430
Right.
So the security professional, the CISSP,

49
00:02:41,430 --> 00:02:46,670
would really be thinking about how to
use confidentiality to put in place

50
00:02:46,670 --> 00:02:50,980
systems that would address the risk of
the exposure of the information and would

51
00:02:50,980 --> 00:02:55,150
govern the use of that information to keep
it secure throughout it's life cycle.

52
00:02:55,150 --> 00:02:58,060
Yeah, making sure that only the authorized
users actually have access to

53
00:02:58,060 --> 00:02:59,130
that information.

54
00:02:59,130 --> 00:03:00,990
Absolutely correct.

55
00:03:00,990 --> 00:03:02,830
So that's where we see confidentiality.

56
00:03:02,830 --> 00:03:05,660
Integrity would be this idea
of accuracy and reliability,

57
00:03:05,660 --> 00:03:07,490
great use of terminology there.

58
00:03:07,490 --> 00:03:12,707
Really focuses, excuse me,
third time's the charm.

59
00:03:12,707 --> 00:03:16,950
[LAUGH] Focus us on the idea
of this protection and

60
00:03:16,950 --> 00:03:19,610
information with confidentiality.

61
00:03:19,610 --> 00:03:23,350
Now let's make sure that
the integrity of the information,

62
00:03:23,350 --> 00:03:27,000
that the information itself has
not been modified in any way,

63
00:03:27,000 --> 00:03:30,000
whether it's in transit,
what we call data on the wire.

64
00:03:30,000 --> 00:03:34,770
You'll often hear us refer to things that
way, or data at rest when it is stored or

65
00:03:34,770 --> 00:03:37,690
somehow sitting in a file
system in the cloud.

66
00:03:37,690 --> 00:03:40,630
That mythical place that all
data seems to disappear into,

67
00:03:40,630 --> 00:03:42,530
never quite know where it is or
what it's doing.

68
00:03:42,530 --> 00:03:46,640
I'm convinced it's out having a good time,
joy riding on the internet somewhere,

69
00:03:46,640 --> 00:03:48,050
then it comes back when we want it.

70
00:03:48,050 --> 00:03:50,260
I think of that Ferris Bueller scene,

71
00:03:50,260 --> 00:03:52,730
from the movie,
where the guy's got the Porsche.

72
00:03:53,860 --> 00:03:56,818
Just coming over that hill, and
flying through the air, slow motioning it

73
00:03:56,818 --> 00:04:01,780
Flying to the valet parker, hair is waving
in the breeze, a crazy look in his eyes.

74
00:04:01,780 --> 00:04:04,260
That's what I think of when I
think of my data and the cloud.

75
00:04:04,260 --> 00:04:07,170
Yeah.
Joy riding through the streets and

76
00:04:07,170 --> 00:04:09,980
byways of the internet in
somebody's borrowed Porsche.

77
00:04:09,980 --> 00:04:10,760
That's right.
That's what I think of.

78
00:04:10,760 --> 00:04:14,320
So when we think of integrity,
we think of this idea.

79
00:04:14,320 --> 00:04:18,610
This focus on information
not being modified.

80
00:04:18,610 --> 00:04:21,480
You have it there at the end of
the definition where it says any

81
00:04:21,480 --> 00:04:23,620
unauthorized modification is prevented.

82
00:04:23,620 --> 00:04:27,530
When we think about availability, we think
about this idea of making sure, again,

83
00:04:27,530 --> 00:04:31,900
great use of vocabulary here,
reliable and timely access to data.

84
00:04:31,900 --> 00:04:34,990
Making sure that individuals,
those that are authorized,

85
00:04:34,990 --> 00:04:39,840
those that have the right to be there, so
we are saying they should see the data.

86
00:04:39,840 --> 00:04:44,090
Now we are going to make sure the data
is available to them when it is time,

87
00:04:44,090 --> 00:04:44,990
whatever that window is.

88
00:04:44,990 --> 00:04:47,720
It could be a two hour window
at the end of a business day,

89
00:04:47,720 --> 00:04:52,669
where they have to compile and close
out some reports, it could be 24 by 7,

90
00:04:52,669 --> 00:04:55,340
can be anything in between.

91
00:04:55,340 --> 00:04:57,720
If the information they need to
do their job is not available,

92
00:04:57,720 --> 00:04:59,540
then I'm not doing my job.

93
00:04:59,540 --> 00:05:02,100
As a CISSP,
we potentially have an issue there.

94
00:05:02,100 --> 00:05:04,540
We may not be doing our job to
the fullest extent that we should be,

95
00:05:04,540 --> 00:05:05,980
absolutely correct.

96
00:05:05,980 --> 00:05:10,050
We want to make sure that we are focused
on these three pillars, very important as

97
00:05:10,050 --> 00:05:13,530
building blocks for everything we do,
everything we talk about in this area.

98
00:05:13,530 --> 00:05:16,690
Having said that, let's move on, let's
talk about some of these other terms.

99
00:05:16,690 --> 00:05:18,750
You've got some really interesting
definition items up there.

100
00:05:18,750 --> 00:05:22,180
I want to make sure we put this
information into context when we think

101
00:05:22,180 --> 00:05:27,030
about information security, and we think
about this idea of managing information,

102
00:05:27,030 --> 00:05:28,845
we really have to start
out with vocabulary.

103
00:05:28,845 --> 00:05:30,910
I often talk about this with my students.

104
00:05:30,910 --> 00:05:35,150
I talk about this in the context of
having conversations with my customers

105
00:05:35,150 --> 00:05:35,805
about this.

106
00:05:35,805 --> 00:05:36,770
Mm-hm.
It's a language.

107
00:05:36,770 --> 00:05:37,460
Right.

108
00:05:37,460 --> 00:05:40,300
If you wanna learn to
be fluent in security,

109
00:05:40,300 --> 00:05:42,490
you have to learn to speak the language.

110
00:05:42,490 --> 00:05:46,310
It's like anything else,
you put time in and you can sit down and

111
00:05:46,310 --> 00:05:47,210
talk to the natives.

112
00:05:47,210 --> 00:05:50,490
If you don't, they're going to know
that you're from somewhere else, and

113
00:05:50,490 --> 00:05:51,980
they're not going to take you seriously.

114
00:05:51,980 --> 00:05:54,810
You find that some people try to use
these terms interchangeably maybe,

115
00:05:54,810 --> 00:06:00,380
not really fully understanding what the
meaning of the word is when they use them.

116
00:06:00,380 --> 00:06:01,282
Or incorrectly.

117
00:06:01,282 --> 00:06:04,065
Incorrectly using it, so in other words,
as you were pointing out trying to use it

118
00:06:04,065 --> 00:06:07,115
over here when, in fact, we're really
talking about something totally unrelated.

119
00:06:07,115 --> 00:06:08,575
It makes it very difficult to your point,

120
00:06:08,575 --> 00:06:11,625
absolutely correct, to communicate and
communicate effectively.

121
00:06:11,625 --> 00:06:15,120
This is the secret, by the way,
there are several secrets associated but

122
00:06:15,120 --> 00:06:19,340
being a CISSP,
contrary to urban myth and legend.

123
00:06:19,340 --> 00:06:21,760
So there are some that
are really important and

124
00:06:21,760 --> 00:06:23,020
some that are often misunderstood.

125
00:06:23,020 --> 00:06:26,990
One of the big ones Mike just hit on is
this idea of effective communication.

126
00:06:26,990 --> 00:06:31,180
Being able to share this knowledge in such
a way that those around you benefit from

127
00:06:31,180 --> 00:06:36,180
your experience and really effectively
creating the opportunity for awareness,

128
00:06:36,180 --> 00:06:37,460
and security awareness.

129
00:06:37,460 --> 00:06:43,470
Awareness of the surrounding,
what we call situational awareness and

130
00:06:43,470 --> 00:06:48,490
in other areas and in other pursuits is
vital to your success both with CISSP and

131
00:06:48,490 --> 00:06:51,710
as somebody who leads security
efforts in any of these areas.

132
00:06:51,710 --> 00:06:54,090
So let's define some of these terms.

133
00:06:54,090 --> 00:06:57,880
We often think of these terms as
being things that we build on.

134
00:06:57,880 --> 00:07:01,290
These are building blocks and
ways in which we will understand

135
00:07:01,290 --> 00:07:04,150
how information is going to
come into our organization.

136
00:07:04,150 --> 00:07:06,670
How we are going to potentially
process it, and how ultimately,

137
00:07:06,670 --> 00:07:08,385
we're going to be able to
manage it through a life cycle.

138
00:07:08,385 --> 00:07:11,920
They're not in exact order, we're going
to play around with the order a little

139
00:07:11,920 --> 00:07:15,110
bit but we do want to talk through them
all, so the order they're in is fine.

140
00:07:15,110 --> 00:07:20,110
But let's start with the threat agent,
I think number two there.

141
00:07:20,110 --> 00:07:23,428
So this idea that it's
as a formal definition.

142
00:07:23,428 --> 00:07:24,290
We'll give you the formal and

143
00:07:24,290 --> 00:07:26,980
then we'll kind of translate
that into normal person speak.

144
00:07:26,980 --> 00:07:27,704
Right.
[LAUGH]

145
00:07:27,704 --> 00:07:30,959
We'll go into English mode here cuz
this is the non-normal person language,

146
00:07:30,959 --> 00:07:34,655
the language of the information security
professionals, the language of obscurity.

147
00:07:34,655 --> 00:07:38,660
[LAUGH] We practice confidentiality,
as we speak in real time.

148
00:07:38,660 --> 00:07:42,300
This idea of threat agents being entities
that can exploit a vulnerability.

149
00:07:42,300 --> 00:07:43,980
So what does that really mean?

150
00:07:43,980 --> 00:07:48,406
What it means is that it is some thing,
a threat agent could be a individual,

151
00:07:48,406 --> 00:07:52,846
it could be a machine, it could be
a machine being used to target something.

152
00:07:52,846 --> 00:07:56,990
It could be a piece of
software acting as malware.

153
00:07:56,990 --> 00:08:00,551
So we're not quite sure what the threat
agent is at this point and it's not as

154
00:08:00,551 --> 00:08:04,131
important to know what it is- In terms

00:53:43,784 --> 00:53:48,374

00:53:48,374 --> 00:53:52,900

00:53:52,900 --> 00:53:57,830

00:53:57,830 --> 00:54:00,040

00:54:00,040 --> 00:54:03,780

00:54:03,780 --> 00:54:06,220

00:54:06,220 --> 00:54:09,000

1063
00:54:09,000 --> 00:54:10,830
it potentially can be an all in one.

00:54:10,830 --> 00:54:14,410
But the route domain controller, or
the enterprise route CA is typically kept

1065
00:54:14,410 --> 00:54:18,870
separate from everything else because

1066
00:54:18,870 --> 00:54:20,000
If we get to it and

1067
00:54:20,000 --> 00:54:24,430

1068
00:54:24,430 --> 00:54:26,880
And so,
we often will set this up as a machine

1069
00:54:26,880 --> 00:54:28,800
separate from the domain controller,
part of the domain but

1070
00:54:28,800 --> 00:54:31,880
separate, we will then
create the enterprise root.

00:54:31,880 --> 00:54:33,150
We will instantiate,

1072

give out the certificates to enable

00:54:36,510 --> 00:54:40,570
We will then typically take that

1074
00:54:40,570 --> 00:54:42,200

1075
00:54:42,200 --> 00:54:45,920
Maybe, done on a laptop and

1076
00:54:45,920 --> 00:54:47,950
Really depends on how

1077
00:54:47,950 --> 00:54:49,790
Sometimes, they're just left up and

00:54:49,790 --> 00:54:53,550
But more often than not,

1079

00:54:58,660 --> 00:55:02,845
Really, the only role that the root RA or

1081
00:55:02,845 --> 00:55:08,465

1082
00:55:08,465 --> 00:55:12,885
the subordinate CAs, to come online and

1083
00:55:12,885 --> 00:55:16,519
And occasionally, it has to do some

1084
00:55:16,519 --> 00:55:18,555

1085

00:55:21,150 --> 00:55:24,238

1087
00:55:24,238 --> 00:55:25,320

00:55:25,320 --> 00:55:29,402

00:55:29,402 --> 00:55:31,818
unless it is the only CA that's available.

1090
00:55:31,818 --> 00:55:33,866
In other words,

1091
00:55:33,866 --> 00:55:36,237

1092
00:55:36,237 --> 00:55:38,335
But in a well architected solution,

00:55:38,335 --> 00:55:41,210

00:55:41,210 --> 00:55:42,070

1097
00:55:49,540 --> 00:55:52,130
The subordinate CA is really

1098
00:55:52,130 --> 00:55:54,560
So, this is where all the certificates for

1099
00:55:54,560 --> 00:55:55,640
They get updated.

1100
00:55:55,640 --> 00:55:59,979
Certificates have a lifetime associated
with them, what's known as the TTL.

1101
00:55:59,979 --> 00:56:01,499
A time to live value.

1102
00:56:01,499 --> 00:56:04,549
It could be a day, it could be a year,
it could be five years.

1103
00:56:04,549 --> 00:56:09,331
We as the owner, the one who creates the
certificate, tends to get to decide based

1104
00:56:09,331 --> 00:56:13,020
on the template that we use,
what kind of scripts that we want?

1105
00:56:13,020 --> 00:56:16,148
And as a result, how long that
certificate is going to be alive for?

1106
00:56:16,148 --> 00:56:19,980
We don't wanna see certificate
lifetimes that are very, very long,

1107
00:56:19,980 --> 00:56:24,810
because the certificates get compromised,
we have to then get rid of them,

1108
00:56:24,810 --> 00:56:26,270
invalidate them, in other words,
and turn them off.

1109
00:56:26,270 --> 00:56:29,890
And we have to put them on what's known as
a CRL or a certification revocation list.

1110
00:56:29,890 --> 00:56:32,250
So if we leave certificates out there for
too long,

1111
00:56:32,250 --> 00:56:33,900
the likelihood is that they
will become compromised.

1112
00:56:33,900 --> 00:56:37,320
So over time, and other words somebody may
actually find a way to take them over.

1113
00:56:37,320 --> 00:56:41,913
So we tend to see, from a best practice
perspective, that we have small TTLs for

1114
00:56:41,913 --> 00:56:45,767
average certificates,
things that are used maybe to sign email.

1115
00:56:45,767 --> 00:56:49,520
Maybe they get a year, maybe they get

00:56:49,520 --> 00:56:54,130

our RTOs and we have no way

01:14:10,340 --> 01:14:12,870

01:14:17,870 --> 01:14:20,360

01:14:23,370 --> 01:14:25,340
Kind of starting point right there.

01:14:25,340 --> 01:14:28,130
So at that point,

01:14:28,130 --> 01:14:31,420
Remember, it's the amount of data

1549
01:14:31,420 --> 01:14:34,950

01:14:34,950 --> 01:14:39,530
So that space right there, up to the RTO

1551
01:14:39,530 --> 01:14:44,310

01:14:45,750 --> 01:14:46,490

01:14:57,210 --> 01:15:00,170

01:15:03,090 --> 01:15:04,470

01:15:19,810 --> 01:15:22,530

1569
01:15:25,220 --> 01:15:30,330

1570
01:15:30,330 --> 01:15:34,130

1571
01:15:34,130 --> 01:15:35,180

1572
01:15:35,180 --> 01:15:40,490

time up to the bar where the MTD stops.

1573
01:15:40,490 --> 01:15:44,180

where we say we must be recovered by

1574
01:15:44,180 --> 01:15:45,300

1575
01:15:45,300 --> 01:15:47,080
It's the drop dead, we often call it.

1576
01:15:47,080 --> 01:15:50,220
The drop dead window, right, where you
gotta be back online no matter what.

1577
01:15:50,220 --> 01:15:51,760

1578
01:15:51,760 --> 01:15:53,720

1579
01:15:53,720 --> 01:15:58,670

01:15:58,670 --> 01:16:02,490

1585

1586
01:16:17,950 --> 01:16:21,880

time, and the amount of data over that

1587
01:16:21,880 --> 01:16:24,350

lose until we start recovery and

1588
01:16:24,350 --> 01:16:28,310

1589
01:16:28,310 --> 01:16:32,740

We'll talk about that, and then we'll talk

around looking at our plans,

kind of laid out, and

So we'll go through and

72
00:03:40,295 --> 00:03:44,855
A non-disaster, in the language of

73
00:03:44,855 --> 00:03:48,555
is this idea of disruption and
service due to some sort of failure but

74
00:03:48,555 --> 00:03:54,032
one that's not going be so critical

75
00:03:54,032 --> 00:03:55,842
So we haven't lost the building,

76
00:03:55,842 --> 00:04:00,002

the building for any period of time.

77
00:04:00,002 --> 00:04:03,930
We really just have an individual

78
00:04:03,930 --> 00:04:08,080

79
00:04:08,080 --> 00:04:11,730

80
00:04:11,730 --> 00:04:16,400
It's something we need to be aware of but

81
00:04:16,400 --> 00:04:21,770

85
00:04:31,020 --> 00:04:32,660

>> It was not quite a disaster but

00:04:37,628 --> 00:04:42,100

00:04:44,580 --> 00:04:48,610

90
00:04:48,610 --> 00:04:51,180
>> Right.
>> As a result, that was a non-disaster

00:04:51,180 --> 00:04:55,740
event for me but obviously, could have
been a little bit more productive.

92
00:04:55,740 --> 00:04:57,220
So that's what you see.

93
00:04:57,220 --> 00:05:01,560
>> With the disaster, we're talking about
events that caused the entire facility of

94
00:05:01,560 --> 00:05:05,290
the office, wherever we are, whatever that
focus is that we're talking about there,

95
00:05:05,290 --> 00:05:09,810
that facility, that building, to be
able to be unusable for a day or longer.

96
00:05:09,810 --> 00:05:13,800
A disaster is something that will
render that area unusable for

97
00:05:13,800 --> 00:05:17,110
a period of time,
typically use a day as a threshold there.

98
00:05:17,110 --> 00:05:20,930
If the event that takes place
causes a disruption in power or

99
00:05:20,930 --> 00:05:22,950
Internet service for
a couple of hours but not for

100
00:05:22,950 --> 00:05:25,860
an entire day,
we'd say it's a non-disaster event.

101
00:05:25,860 --> 00:05:29,390
If it took us down for a day or
longer, it would then be a disaster.

102
00:05:29,390 --> 00:05:29,930
Right.

103
00:05:29,930 --> 00:05:31,460
>> So just think about that.

104
00:05:31,460 --> 00:05:34,390
Then a catastrophe is a major disruption,
not just hey,

105
00:05:34,390 --> 00:05:38,850
we lost power, it's going to be out for 12
hours, so go home and come back tomorrow.

106
00:05:38,850 --> 00:05:42,300
A disaster that really can
take down something and

107
00:05:42,300 --> 00:05:44,780
knock it out totally
we call a catastrophe.

108
00:05:44,780 --> 00:05:48,560
That's where maybe the building gets
damaged, we're not able to use it.

109
00:05:48,560 --> 00:05:50,690
At that point,
perhaps it's even destroyed.

110
00:05:50,690 --> 00:05:54,630
It could be a fire, some sort of
severe weather event could do this.

111
00:05:54,630 --> 00:05:59,420
Maybe a hurricane or some sort of a snow
storm or a flood, whatever it may be,

112
00:05:59,420 --> 00:06:03,340
that is going to be a catastrophe and
that's how we're going to categorize that.

113
00:06:03,340 --> 00:06:06,630

114

Something happened, and
you didn't get it done.

1029
00:45:50,375 --> 00:45:53,585
And we had to push the audit back because
we had to make sure the test results were

1030
00:45:53,585 --> 00:45:54,875
in before we could do the audit.

1031
00:45:54,875 --> 00:45:56,825
Right?
So just be aware of that.

1032
00:45:56,825 --> 00:45:59,316
So having said that, let's just
quickly go through the test types.

1033
00:45:59,316 --> 00:46:00,917
Right?
So we have what's called a checklist.

1034
00:46:00,917 --> 00:46:04,807
Sometimes this test is also
referred to as the desk check test,

1035
00:46:04,807 --> 00:46:06,217
these are kind of the same thing.

1036
00:46:06,217 --> 00:46:09,877
We basically send printed copies,
electronic or printed, either way, but

1037
00:46:09,877 --> 00:46:13,867
just basically copies, usually
electronic of this around to everybody.

1038
00:46:13,867 --> 00:46:15,587
Say hey, kind of sit at your desk.

1039
00:46:15,587 --> 00:46:17,447
Look at it, look at your piece.

1040
00:46:17,447 --> 00:46:18,807
Kind of walk it through.

1041
00:46:18,807 --> 00:46:22,690
Check off the pieces you're
responsible for, and make sure

1042
00:46:22,690 --> 00:46:26,460
that from a functional review perspective,
you're familiar with what's in there.

1043
00:46:26,460 --> 00:46:27,540
And you're okay with it.

1044
00:46:27,540 --> 00:46:29,375
Nothing's changed,
you don't have any input.

1045
00:46:29,375 --> 00:46:31,060
Oh, it's not this anymore.

1046
00:46:31,060 --> 00:46:32,380
Hey, we changed this thing.

1047
00:46:32,380 --> 00:46:33,215
We don't have this system.

1048
00:46:33,215 --> 00:46:34,840
>> Yeah.
>> That kind of stuff comes back.

1049
00:46:34,840 --> 00:46:37,200
But you basically just,
it's done in isolation.

1050
00:46:37,200 --> 00:46:41,190
People aren't in the same room together,
you just do a read through.

1051
00:46:41,190 --> 00:46:44,080
And it's very, very basic dry run,
and we check it off.

1052
00:46:44,080 --> 00:46:45,130
That's why we call it a checklist,

1053
00:46:45,130 --> 00:46:47,780
we just literally check off
a box that says we read it.

1054
00:46:47,780 --> 00:46:50,900
And we may provide some feedback, and
then that's the extent of the test.

1055
00:46:50,900 --> 00:46:51,790
Nothing else is done.

1056
00:46:51,790 --> 00:46:53,020
So totally paper based.

1057
00:46:53,020 --> 00:46:53,990
We don't do anything.

1058
00:46:53,990 --> 00:46:57,380
We don't look at any real systems,
we don't do anything of that kind at all.

1059
00:46:57,380 --> 00:46:59,930
The next kind is called
a structured walk through.

1060
00:46:59,930 --> 00:47:03,620
Structured walk through is where we get
representatives in from each department.

1061
00:47:03,620 --> 00:47:07,270
So if we have HR,
if we have sales and marketing.

1062
00:47:07,270 --> 00:47:08,420
We have finance.

1063
00:47:09,530 --> 00:47:12,270
We have database.

1064
00:47:12,270 --> 00:47:13,640
We have directory services.

1065
00:47:13,640 --> 00:47:14,850
We have networking.

1066
00:47:14,850 --> 00:47:15,970
We have all those different departments.

1067
00:47:15,970 --> 00:47:18,490
They all come in,
sit together in a room basically.

1068
00:47:18,490 --> 00:47:21,640
Everybody has copies again, so
you gotta print out a bunch of copies.

1069
00:47:21,640 --> 00:47:23,800
And we come together,
and we go over the plan.

1070
00:47:23,800 --> 00:47:25,870
Again, totally on paper.

1071
00:47:25,870 --> 00:47:27,740
We're not actually
bringing up live systems.

1072
00:47:27,740 --> 00:47:31,180
We don't touch anything but now we've
got all the players in a single room

1073
00:47:31,180 --> 00:47:35,930
talking to each other, basically
helping us understand what is going on.

1074
00:47:35,930 --> 00:47:38,840
But again we're just reading
through the plan in effect, but

1075
00:47:38,840 --> 00:47:42,600
we're going through it kind of
top to bottom in order there.

1076
00:47:42,600 --> 00:47:43,750
So that way, we have a sense and

1077
00:47:43,750 --> 00:47:45,990
everybody kind of chimes in and
says what's going on.

1078
00:47:47,640 --> 00:47:48,660
Then we have a simulation.

1079
00:47:48,660 --> 00:47:52,390
So this is like, I used to call this
the Dungeons and Dragons test, right?

1080
00:47:52,390 --> 00:47:55,703
Because the simulation test is,
you come up with a scenario, right?

1081
00:47:55,703 --> 00:47:59,404
So, okay, we're going to simulate
today that we had, if you were out,

1082
00:47:59,404 --> 00:48:03,062
let's say in California Did this
a few times with companies out there.

1083
00:48:03,062 --> 00:48:06,301
So we just had a level four earthquake.

1084
00:48:06,301 --> 00:48:08,450
It was 7.0 on the Richter scale.

1085
00:48:09,460 --> 00:48:14,300
Power's out, we have fires all over
the place, and the data center's offline.

1086
00:48:14,300 --> 00:48:15,430
So that's our scenario.

1087
00:48:15,430 --> 00:48:17,160
Now let's kinda walk through the scenario.

1088
00:48:17,160 --> 00:48:20,220
And everybody's in the room,
you got all the key players there.

1089
00:48:20,220 --> 00:48:23,180
Again, it's paper based in
the sense it's a scenario.

1090
00:48:23,180 --> 00:48:25,000
You're not touching real systems.

1091
00:48:25,000 --> 00:48:29,880
But you are gonna go through, and you are
gonna basically see what's going on there.

1092
00:48:29,880 --> 00:48:32,370
And so, we're gonna simulate this, and

1093
00:48:32,370 --> 00:48:35,150
we're gonna simulate
the operational issues.

1094
00:48:35,150 --> 00:48:37,805
So people are gonna act
like it's really happening.

1095
00:48:37,805 --> 00:48:40,755
They're gonna sit at the console,
they're gonna basically be playing and

1096
00:48:40,755 --> 00:48:41,615
doing these things.

1097
00:48:41,615 --> 00:48:43,716
But we're not gonna
actually fail systems over,

1098
00:48:43,716 --> 00:48:45,575
we're not really gonna touch production.

1099
00:48:45,575 --> 00:48:47,505
>> Right.
>> We're just gonna kinda walk through

1100
00:48:47,505 --> 00:48:48,365
what that's gonna look like.

1101
00:48:48,365 --> 00:48:52,865
It's either called a simulation or
scenario exam, or a simulation or

1102
00:48:52,865 --> 00:48:53,965
scenario test.

1103
00:48:53,965 --> 00:48:57,965
But the idea is that basically you're
picking a scenario problem, a what if, and

1104
00:48:57,965 --> 00:49:01,160
you're walking through what the plan
looks like from that perspective.

1105
00:49:01,160 --> 00:49:02,040
So just be aware of that.

1106
00:49:03,530 --> 00:49:05,620
Then we have what's known
as a parallel test.

1107
00:49:05,620 --> 00:49:08,770
Parallel test is where we have
some systems that are interrupted.

1108
00:49:08,770 --> 00:49:11,320
So, this is where we start
actually going live on systems.

1109
00:49:11,320 --> 00:49:13,695
We're gonna pick some subsets of system.

1110
00:49:13,695 --> 00:49:14,905
Fail them over.

1111
00:49:14,905 --> 00:49:17,215
Interrupt them to the recovery site.

1112
00:49:17,215 --> 00:49:20,545
Run them from there for
a period of time and then fail them back.

1113
00:49:20,545 --> 00:49:22,799
And so, we're not gonna fail
the entire system over, but

1114
00:49:22,799 --> 00:49:26,355
we may just decide to say, hey, you
know what, we're gonna fail over email.

1115
00:49:26,355 --> 00:49:30,145
So, this weekend is our parallel test,
our parallel DR test for email.

1116
00:49:31,375 --> 00:49:35,180
We fail over the email system to
the recovery site, we run email there for

1117
00:49:35,180 --> 00:49:37,690
24 hours, and then we fail it back.

1118
00:49:37,690 --> 00:49:41,920
And so the idea is to test different
areas or aspects of our architecture

1119
00:49:41,920 --> 00:49:45,820
in order to ensure that when we do go
to a full failover in the real thing,

1120
00:49:45,820 --> 00:49:47,310
that hopefully it works.

1121
00:49:47,310 --> 00:49:50,360
So there's some value in this in
the sense you get to see a slice

1122
00:49:50,360 --> 00:49:51,860
of the system failing over.

1123
00:49:51,860 --> 00:49:54,600
The downside here, the lack of clarity is,

1124
00:49:54,600 --> 00:49:58,100
because the entire structure
doesn't failover at once, right?

1125
00:49:58,100 --> 00:50:00,135
What I often find, I've had this
happen with a lot of clients,

1126
00:50:00,135 --> 00:50:03,560
is that piece works really well,
the failover on the routing for

1127
00:50:03,560 --> 00:50:07,680
the email works well, but there's problems
in the routing topology elsewhere.

1128
00:50:07,680 --> 00:50:11,140
And we don't see them until
we failover the whole system.

1129
00:50:11,140 --> 00:50:15,850
So as a result, that part works flawlessly
and they check it off, okay, we're good.

1130
00:50:15,850 --> 00:50:18,980
And then something happens six months
later before the next test and

1131
00:50:18,980 --> 00:50:21,180
they failover everything for real.

1132
00:50:21,180 --> 00:50:24,800
And all of a sudden while email may be up
and running, VoIP is hosed because you

1133
00:50:24,800 --> 00:50:28,750
can't get the routing topology for
VoIP to failover, because your layer three

1134
00:50:28,750 --> 00:50:32,270
switches, you know, there was a firmware
update nobody did it or something crazy.

1135
00:50:32,270 --> 00:50:35,390
Or they did do it and it screwed up
the failover because now they wiped out

1136
00:50:35,390 --> 00:50:37,950
the routes that are supposed
to be there for failover.

1137
00:50:37,950 --> 00:50:40,960
So, I've seen all sorts of really crazy,
bizarre things happen.

1138
00:50:40,960 --> 00:50:45,420
They usually happen outside of testing,
because they happen in between tests.

1139
00:50:45,420 --> 00:50:48,690
And then nobody really understands the
implication of them cuz we're not doing

1140
00:50:48,690 --> 00:50:50,360
a full failover, we're don't see it.

1141
00:50:50,360 --> 00:50:51,570
So that's really an issue.

1142
00:50:51,570 --> 00:50:52,670
And then full interruption.

1143
00:50:53,830 --> 00:50:56,302
Full interruption,
like the name implies, right?

1144
00:50:56,302 --> 00:51:00,295
We're gonna basically just
take the entire system and

1145
00:51:00,295 --> 00:51:04,140
fail it over to whatever
is our recovery option.

1146
00:51:04,140 --> 00:51:07,940
And so this is literally like walking
out behind the back of the shed,

1147
00:51:07,940 --> 00:51:12,110
pulling the bower plug out of the entire
business and just seeing what happens.

1148
00:51:12,110 --> 00:51:16,110
And we obviously have a full team in place
at the recovery site, and everybody is

1149
00:51:16,110 --> 00:51:20,490
set up in the knock or whatever's gonna be
online to manage this, and we're running,

1150
00:51:20,490 --> 00:51:23,310
in effect, the entire business from
over there for a period of time.

1151
00:51:23,310 --> 00:51:26,860
And then of course we're failing back
over once that recovery solution

1152
00:51:26,860 --> 00:51:27,740
has been tested.

1153
00:51:27,740 --> 00:51:30,372
And this is really typically where
we tend to shake things out and

1154
00:51:30,372 --> 00:51:31,795
find the issues I just discussed.

1155
00:51:31,795 --> 00:51:35,847
Where maybe there's a routing topology
problem, maybe there is some sort of

1156
00:51:35,847 --> 00:51:39,794
redundancy problem where the redundant
system isn't fully spinning up.

1157
00:51:39,794 --> 00:51:43,149
A lot of times, what we see is even
though these systems are maintained,

1158
00:51:43,149 --> 00:51:45,290
there could be things like I mentioned.

1159
00:51:45,290 --> 00:51:47,460
Some sort of a patch to firmware.

1160
00:51:47,460 --> 00:51:51,980
Some sort of an update that we've engaged
in part of the scenario or part of

1161
00:51:51,980 --> 00:51:55,880
the system, where maybe we're starting to
do rip and replace around certain gear.

1162
00:51:55,880 --> 00:51:59,950
So certain gear has been updated, but then
maybe the recovery gear has not been, or

1163
00:51:59,950 --> 00:52:03,520
has not been fully updated,
so you're mixed topologies.

1164
00:52:03,520 --> 00:52:07,290
And as a result of that, we tend to then
have issues where there's mismatches, and

1165
00:52:07,290 --> 00:52:08,050
as a result,

1166
00:52:08,050 --> 00:52:10,820
we tend to have problems because we're
not operating on the same level.

1167
00:52:10,820 --> 00:52:12,760
Different protocols may be
involved at that point,

1168
00:52:12,760 --> 00:52:15,560
different configurations,
different abilities.

1169
00:52:15,560 --> 00:52:18,600
When we do a firmware update we
tend to see different abilities.

1170
00:52:18,600 --> 00:52:20,020
Different things come online.

1171
00:52:20,020 --> 00:52:22,090
So that's usually something
that will take place.

1172
00:52:22,090 --> 00:52:26,900
So these are all the different kinds
of tests that we actually can see and

1173
00:52:26,900 --> 00:52:27,690
we run through.

1174
00:52:27,690 --> 00:52:28,870
And again, to be clear,

1175
00:52:28,870 --> 00:52:33,360
a company should be doing more than
one of these every time they test.

1176
00:52:33,360 --> 00:52:35,030
But they will do a mixture of these.

1177
00:52:35,030 --> 00:52:38,460
So literally every two or three months, I
have customers that'll do different kinds

1178
00:52:38,460 --> 00:52:41,530
of tests to test a plan at different
levels all throughout the year.

1179
00:52:41,530 --> 00:52:46,130
So they may start out with some basic
walk-through, structured testing.

1180
00:52:46,130 --> 00:52:50,090
But on paper, they may migrate towards
the middle of the year to things like

1181
00:52:50,090 --> 00:52:51,880
parallel tests or scenario tests.

1182
00:52:51,880 --> 00:52:54,810
Then ultimately end up the year
with a full interruption

1183
00:52:54,810 --> 00:52:56,510
where they're actually gonna go
through and do the whole thing.

1184
00:52:56,510 --> 00:52:58,850
>> Some of those tests are not
quite as resource intensive, so

1185
00:52:58,850 --> 00:53:02,030
you might actually be able to do them a
little more often, where I'm not actually

1186
00:53:02,030 --> 00:53:03,520
failing systems over, and-
>> Right,

1187
00:53:03,520 --> 00:53:06,040
a structured walkthrough, a checklist
is really just buying people lunch.

1188
00:53:06,040 --> 00:53:07,480
Checklist is not even that.

1189
00:53:07,480 --> 00:53:09,520
Just say, hey, give me an hour,
and we're gonna do that.

1190
00:53:09,520 --> 00:53:10,520
But a structured walk-through,

1191
00:53:10,520 --> 00:53:13,300
you're basically putting everybody in a
room, you're buying them food for the day.

1192
00:53:13,300 --> 00:53:14,870
I mean, it's very inexpensive.

1193
00:53:14,870 --> 00:53:18,140
But a parallel test, you gotta put
people on planes, fly them out there.

1194
00:53:18,140 --> 00:53:19,320
>> Right.
>> They've got to stay there for

1195
00:53:19,320 --> 00:53:20,550
a few days, right?

1196
00:53:20,550 --> 00:53:22,690
They gotta come back,
you gotta failover, failback.

1197
00:53:22,690 --> 00:53:26,250
So no, there's definitely expense
associated with that, no doubt about it.

1198
00:53:26,250 --> 00:53:26,750
Absolutely.

1199
00:53:26,750 --> 00:53:27,920
All right, very good.

1200
00:53:27,920 --> 00:53:31,872
So I think we are at a completion point,
as opposed to a stopping point.

1201
00:53:31,872 --> 00:53:33,230
>> Yeah, I think so too.

1202
00:53:33,230 --> 00:53:34,270
That was a good episode.

1203
00:53:34,270 --> 00:53:36,600
I love the business continuity and
disaster recovery.

1204
00:53:36,600 --> 00:53:38,130
All right, ladies and gentlemen,

1205
00:53:38,130 --> 00:53:41,560
I hope you guys enjoy the show as
much as we did doing it for you.

1206

Remember, if you have questions during
the show, anytime you've got a question,

a recorded version of this,

1216
00:54:04,140 --> 00:54:07,150
If you're away from your computer and
you wanna check it out,

1217
00:54:07,150 --> 00:54:09,560
make sure you tune in your Roku,
to the ITProTV channel.

1218
00:54:10,720 --> 00:54:12,450
I think that'll do it.

1219
00:54:12,450 --> 00:54:15,450
So signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

1220
00:54:15,450 --> 00:54:17,573
>> And I'm Adam Gordon,

trespassed and now you're under arrest.

517
00:23:52,424 --> 00:23:53,430
Right?
That kind of thing.

518
00:23:53,430 --> 00:23:55,289
You can't do that.
So entrapment is illegal but

519
00:23:55,289 --> 00:23:57,410
enticement is seen as being legal.

520
00:23:57,410 --> 00:24:00,275
Please make sure you are comfortable
with the difference between the two.

521
00:24:00,275 --> 00:24:04,701
Wanna make sure, even though we may not
really see this distinction very often,

522
00:24:04,701 --> 00:24:09,194
in practice especially, unless you're
engaging in things like either on the law

523
00:24:09,194 --> 00:24:13,297
enforcement side or occasionally having
to testify as an expert witness or

524
00:24:13,297 --> 00:24:15,600
things like to somebody's activities.

525
00:24:15,600 --> 00:24:18,760
You may never see this distinction
in production in other words.

526
00:24:18,760 --> 00:24:20,690
But it is important to understand it and
just be aware of it.

527
00:24:20,690 --> 00:24:21,830
So wanna make sure we do that.

528
00:24:22,900 --> 00:24:24,670
And then,
we wanna talk a bit about attack types.

529
00:24:26,000 --> 00:24:29,020
So the idea with attack types is really
just quickly going through and kind of

530
00:24:29,020 --> 00:24:32,900
helping us to understand that there are
different kinds of attacks we may face.

531
00:24:32,900 --> 00:24:35,170
And so we just wanna review them,
just be aware of them.

532
00:24:35,170 --> 00:24:36,750
Something called a Salami Attack.

533
00:24:36,750 --> 00:24:39,030
This is where we take
a bunch of small attacks and

534
00:24:39,030 --> 00:24:41,890
kind of roll them up,
little by little, nibble away here and

535
00:24:41,890 --> 00:24:45,580
there, with the hopes that the larger
goal of the overall attack type

536
00:24:45,580 --> 00:24:49,525
is not gonna be seen because we break it
up in effects like a fragmentation attack.

537
00:24:49,525 --> 00:24:51,025
But we call it a Salami Attack.

538
00:24:51,025 --> 00:24:53,975
It's often gonna happen
in financial areas.

539
00:24:53,975 --> 00:24:56,165
So that old, urban myth and legend about,

540
00:24:56,165 --> 00:25:00,265
if we just knock a penny off each
transaction or just skim it off the top,

541
00:25:00,265 --> 00:25:04,745
that kind of thing,
a roundup to the next whole number.

542
00:25:04,745 --> 00:25:09,165
In a financial system we skim all that off
the top, we could become billionaires,

543
00:25:09,165 --> 00:25:10,870
literally if it goes on long enough.

544
00:25:10,870 --> 00:25:13,500
And there have been evidence of
these kinds of attacks in the past.

545
00:25:13,500 --> 00:25:17,360
Certain well-known documented stories
about certain kinds of attacks that have

546
00:25:17,360 --> 00:25:19,510
occurred in this light over the years.

547
00:25:19,510 --> 00:25:22,380
But generically, we call this
a Salami Attack, so just be aware of that.

548
00:25:23,540 --> 00:25:24,870
Data Diddling.

549
00:25:24,870 --> 00:25:28,520
Data Diddling is the idea of
altering existing data in some way.

550
00:25:28,520 --> 00:25:32,700
So if we go in and modify data, we refer
to that as a Data Diddling attack.

551
00:25:32,700 --> 00:25:34,187
We'd try to say that with a straight face

552
00:25:34,187 --> 00:25:34,772
at all times-
>> [LAUGH]

553
00:25:34,772 --> 00:25:36,410
>> And never laugh, while we say that.

554
00:25:36,410 --> 00:25:39,390
Or it's like a tickle me
emo kind of attack, but

555
00:25:39,390 --> 00:25:41,430
that's what we talk about there.

556
00:25:41,430 --> 00:25:45,830
Password sniffing, effectively monitoring
a network to gather passwords.

557
00:25:45,830 --> 00:25:48,870
So whatever software there may
be that you will use to do that.

558
00:25:48,870 --> 00:25:52,330
Hence, the reason we often talk about
confidentiality and encrypting data, so

559
00:25:52,330 --> 00:25:54,350
we don't send our passwords in the clear.

560
00:25:54,350 --> 00:25:57,720
IP Spoofing, this is also sometimes
referred to as a masquerading or

561
00:25:57,720 --> 00:25:59,740
at least a form of a masquerade attack.

562
00:25:59,740 --> 00:26:03,020
We effectively take on the guise
of somebody else's IP address.

563
00:26:03,020 --> 00:26:05,672
So we use it and
pretend to be them, in effect.

564
00:26:05,672 --> 00:26:07,760
We could do this with MAC
addresses as well, by the way.

565
00:26:07,760 --> 00:26:11,550
We have MAC address spoofing attacks and
tools that will help you to do that.

566
00:26:11,550 --> 00:26:15,360
I'm not very common, but
often we do see this in some kinds and

567
00:26:15,360 --> 00:26:16,860
some forms of attacks.

568
00:26:16,860 --> 00:26:20,810
Dumpster Diving where we go and basically
rummage through the trash looking for

569
00:26:20,810 --> 00:26:23,530
unshredded documents, thrown away manuals,

570
00:26:23,530 --> 00:26:28,360
perhaps discarded media that may have
data remnants on it, whatever it may be.

571
00:26:28,360 --> 00:26:29,650
Form of social engineering,

572
00:26:29,650 --> 00:26:32,940
we do consider dumpster diving to
be a form of social engineering.

573
00:26:32,940 --> 00:26:35,925
So please make that connection and
be aware of that distinction.

574
00:26:35,925 --> 00:26:39,970
Wire-tapping, where we effectively
tap either the phone line or

575
00:26:39,970 --> 00:26:42,910
these days it may be Internet related
traffic that's going back and

576
00:26:42,910 --> 00:26:45,090
forth, like void traffic,
something like that.

577
00:26:45,090 --> 00:26:46,155
But however we get there,

578
00:26:46,155 --> 00:26:49,640
wire-tapping traditionally used to
refer to tapping analog phone lines.

579
00:26:49,640 --> 00:26:51,060
That's kind of where we got it from.

580
00:26:51,060 --> 00:26:53,020
Cuz you used to have to go down
to the switching office, and

581
00:26:53,020 --> 00:26:55,280
actually tap into the line
in order to listen to.

582
00:26:55,280 --> 00:26:57,340
And that's where the name came from.

583
00:26:57,340 --> 00:27:00,200
But the ideas are considered
to be a passive attack.

584
00:27:00,200 --> 00:27:02,540
So it's an attack that does
not actively do anything.

585
00:27:02,540 --> 00:27:04,690
We're just kind of recording and
passively listening.

586
00:27:04,690 --> 00:27:06,890
And then we have this
idea of cyber squatting.

587
00:27:07,930 --> 00:27:11,360
Cyber Squatting is this
idea of taking over a name,

588
00:27:11,360 --> 00:27:15,060
a fully qualified domain name, or a name
registration, either on the Internet or

589
00:27:15,060 --> 00:27:18,530
World Wide Web or
perhaps in a network of some kind.

590
00:27:18,530 --> 00:27:23,260
And using it to your advantage meaning,
in effect either blackmailing

591
00:27:23,260 --> 00:27:27,190
the person who owns it to get it back or
charging them or something like that.

592
00:27:27,190 --> 00:27:29,530
It is now,
there are laws that make this illegal.

593
00:27:29,530 --> 00:27:33,190
Early on, in the kind of Wild West days
of the Internet, the World Wide Web,

594
00:27:33,190 --> 00:27:37,840
especially, this was done a lot, and there
was really no way to defend against it,

595
00:27:37,840 --> 00:27:40,400
cuz there were no laws that said
it was illegal for you to register

596
00:27:40,400 --> 00:27:43,760
someone else's namespace if it was
available and you got to it first.

597
00:27:43,760 --> 00:27:45,370
You didn't have to use
it in order to own it.

598
00:27:45,370 --> 00:27:46,500
You just had to own it.

599
00:27:46,500 --> 00:27:49,990
Now, we say you have to register it, but
you have to show commercial use of it.

600
00:27:49,990 --> 00:27:51,710
If you don't really have
a viable reason for

601
00:27:51,710 --> 00:27:53,950
owning it,
we effectively can take it away from you.

602
00:27:53,950 --> 00:27:56,690
The courts can basically mandate
you have to give it back.

603
00:27:56,690 --> 00:28:01,540
So this was all the rage a few years ago,
and it does come up again pretty

604
00:28:01,540 --> 00:28:04,380
much every four years, around
elections in the United States anyway.

605
00:28:04,380 --> 00:28:08,750
Presidential elections, people go out and
register all the domain derivatives for

606
00:28:08,750 --> 00:28:09,790
the candidates.

607
00:28:09,790 --> 00:28:13,010
And if one becomes president they
try to then effectively own that.

608
00:28:13,010 --> 00:28:15,710
So it happened to George W.Bush,
a little bit,

609
00:28:15,710 --> 00:28:18,290
where everybody was trying to
register stuff around him.

610
00:28:18,290 --> 00:28:21,630
So that kind of thing, and
that's why we talk about that.

611
00:28:21,630 --> 00:28:24,980
So then we have, just the last item we
want to talk about the code of ethics.

612
00:28:26,140 --> 00:28:30,600
So the ISC squared Code of Ethics is
very important as a CISSP candidate.

613
00:28:30,600 --> 00:28:33,420
Wanna make sure you are aware of
the Code of Ethics, the URL for

614
00:28:33,420 --> 00:28:36,500
the Code of Ethics on
the landing page is there.

615
00:28:36,500 --> 00:28:38,640
And we would encourage you to go out and
take a look,

616
00:28:38,640 --> 00:28:41,880
you will definitely wanna make sure
you understand the Code of Ethics.

617
00:28:41,880 --> 00:28:43,600
You will be asked to adhere to it.

618
00:28:43,600 --> 00:28:47,260
Once you pass the exam and

619
00:28:47,260 --> 00:28:51,530

sign as part of your application process

620
00:28:51,530 --> 00:28:54,480
